Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back simply marked, with single line indicating clypeus and for prothorax, no elytra; at side, legs marked with horizontal line; underside with stamped (rather than incised) representation of recumbent ibex and sun-disc above its back; an unidentified sign in front, now worn off (according to Petrie's drawing a nefer sign); longitudinally pierced; glaze gone; pale buff yellow core; badly abraded.
Curator's comments: If the identification is correct, the scarab got damaged after the drawing by Petrie (Petrie 1886, pl. 37, 19). Ibex was a popular motif on Naukratite scarabs and scaraboids (on the ‘Scarab Factory’ productions, see Webb forthcoming). Different versions of that motif are known (Petrie 1886, pl. 37, 15-19; Gardner 1888, pl. 18, 10-13, 15). It belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93, 96-97, 106-107, type XXVIII A, see especially A118-126 for this piece). Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, 'Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site', in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming, Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 19)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.036) (phase 3)
Condition: Badly abraded, with part of one end broken off, and motif on underside partly destroyed
